awd_titl_txt: Travel: DEF CON31 AI Village Travel
awd_abstract_narration:
This conference proposal requests funds to support student participation in the DEF CON 31 computer security conference, scheduled for August 10-13, 2023, in Las Vegas, Nevada. The DEF CON conference brings together computer security professionals, journalists, lawyers, federal government employees, security researchers, and students with an interest in cybersecurity for all aspects of computer systems, including software, computer architecture, and hardware. The event includes “villages” that are dedicated spaces arranged around a specific topic. This year the AI Village is hosting the first public generative AI cybersecurity event focused on testing several industrial AI platforms.  The funds will be used to provide travel support for twenty-seven community college students. This support will broaden participation in computing, expand the dissemination of the latest research results on AI and cybersecurity, and help to build the workforce for secure AI products and systems.

The goals of this project include informing the development of AI models and products, and gaining a better understanding of opportunities for community colleges to provide experiential learning to students interested in AI development, management, and security. SeedAI will partner with Houston Community College to recruit and select students using an application process. Students selected for the travel support will contribute to a large-scale security exercise for AI models, working alongside other attendees of the conference.  The project will allow students to inform the high growth field of computer science, networking, cloud, and high-performance computing environments. Students will also meet and engage with peers in the field and develop an understanding of how hackathons work and why they can be important tools for AI and computing development. Students from underrepresented groups and students of color will benefit from their participation by acquiring insight and access that positions them to pursue higher degrees in computing and AI development, infrastructure creation, and management; step confidently into AI careers, and inform AI system infrastructure with their unique and diverse perspectives. Approximately sixty-five percent of Houston Community College students are Black, indigenous or people of color and 25% of those are enrolled in the AI, computing, and engineering tracks. The larger scientific and computing community will benefit from voices that represent communities commonly left out of the AI narrative.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview:

SeedAI is a nonprofit organization dedicated to promoting the ethical and responsible development of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. In 2023, SeedAI partnered with several organizations and federal agencies, including the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP), to host the AI Village at DEF CON 31, one of the world's premier cybersecurity conferences. The centerpiece of this collaboration was the largest-ever Generative AI Red Team challenge, designed to explore the potential risks and vulnerabilities of AI systems.

The AI Village provided a unique platform for participants to engage with cutting-edge AI technologies, gain hands-on experience, and collaborate with experts in the field. By bringing together a diverse group of stakeholders, including community college students, university students, and professionals from various sectors, SeedAI fostered an environment of learning and innovation. With the NSF funding provided for this project, SeedAI was able to sponsor the travel and badge fees of 25 students to participate in the AI Village and network with their peers and leaders in the AI space.

Major Goals and Accomplishments:

  • Diverse Participation and Engagement: SeedAI was successful in engaging a diverse group of participants, including the 25 selected and sponsored by the project funding. The AI Village attracted over 2,200 individuals, including over 90 community college students, 40 university students, and 50 members from Black Tech Street, a nonprofit organization dedicated to increasing diversity in technology. This diverse representation not only enriched the discussions but also demonstrated the broad appeal and relevance of the AI Village across different educational and professional sectors.

  • Raising Awareness and Promoting Responsible AI Development: Bringing students from diverse backgrounds to participate in the largest-ever generative AI red team exercise, not only provided those students with hands-on experience in AI but added typically marginalized perspectives to the discussion of responsible AI. Discussions at the AI Village raised awareness about the ethical implications of AI and promoted responsible development practices. Through the Generative AI Red Team challenge, participants had the opportunity to interact with AI models, identify potential vulnerabilities, and explore ways to mitigate risks associated with these technologies.

Key Outcomes

  • Influential Feedback and Call to Action: The AI Village generated significant interest and positive feedback from influential figures in the technology and policy sectors. Notably, Dr. Arati Prabhakar, the Director of the White House OSTP, participated in the challenge and subsequently launched a call to action for more safeguards in AI development, underscoring the significance of the event.

  • Active Engagement and Communication: The volume of communication during the event, with nearly 165,000 messages exchanged between participants and AI models, highlights the active engagement, discussions, queries, and real-time problem-solving that took place.

Impact on the Discipline and Broader Community

The AI Village at DEF CON 31 had a profound impact on the broader AI and cybersecurity communities. By providing a platform for hands-on exploration and collaboration, the event contributed to a better understanding of the potential risks and vulnerabilities associated with AI technologies. This knowledge is crucial for developing robust safeguards and promoting responsible AI development practices.

Furthermore, the event's emphasis on diversity and inclusion helped to promote greater representation and participation in the field of AI, fostering a more inclusive and equitable environment for innovation and growth.

Future Plans

Building on the success of the DEF CON 31 AI Village, SeedAI plans to continue its efforts in promoting ethical and responsible AI development. Future initiatives may include expanding the reach of the Generative AI Red Team challenge, fostering collaboration with academic institutions and industry partners, and developing educational resources and training programs to equip the next generation of AI professionals with the necessary skills and knowledge.

Additionally, SeedAI aims to strengthen its technical infrastructure and streamline logistics and communication channels to ensure smoother execution of future events and initiatives.

Conclusion

The DEF CON 31 AI Village, hosted in partnership with the White House OSTP, was a resounding success that showcased SeedAI's commitment to ethical and responsible AI development. By providing a platform for hands-on exploration, collaboration, and education, the event contributed to a better understanding of the potential risks and vulnerabilities associated with AI technologies. The diverse participation and positive feedback from influential figures underscore the significance of this initiative and its impact on the broader AI and cybersecurity communities. As SeedAI looks to the future, it remains dedicated to fostering responsible AI development practices and ensuring that these technologies are accessible, inclusive, and beneficial to society.


 

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2024
Modified by: Austin Carson
